revision.text:
In [[traditional Chinese medicine|Traditional Chinese Medicine]], there are roughly 13,000 medicinals used in China and over 100,000 medicinal prescriptions recorded in the ancient literature.<ref name="Certainprogress">Certain progress of clinical research on Chinese integrative medicine, Keji Chen, Bei Yu, Chinese Medical Journal, 1999, 112 (10), p. 934, [http://wenku.baidu.com/view/dfc192a0b0717fd5360cdc44.html]</ref> Plant elements and extracts are the most common elements used in medicines.<ref name="Foster">Foster & Yue 1992, p.11</ref> In the classic ''Handbook of Traditional Drugs'' from 1941, 517 drugs were listed - 442 were plant parts, 45 were animal parts, and 30 were minerals.<ref name="Foster" />
Herbal medicine, as used in traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), came to widespread attention in the United States in the 1970s. At least 40 states in the United States license practitioners of Oriental medicine, and there are about 50 colleges of Oriental medicine in the United States today.<ref>http://www.cancer.org/Treatment/TreatmentsandSideEffects/ComplementaryandAlternativeMedicine/HerbsVitaminsandMinerals/chinese-herbal-medicine</ref>
In Japan, the use of TCM herbs and herbal formulas is traditionally known as [[Kampo]], literally "Han Chinese Medical Formulas". Many Kampo combinations are manufactured in Japan on a large scale by reputable manufacturers.<ref>http://www.med.nyu.edu/content?ChunkIID=37410</ref>
In Korea, more than 5000 herbs and 7000 herbal formulas are used in [[Traditional Korean Medicine]] for the prevention and treatment of ailments. These are herbs and formulas that are traditionally Korean or derived from, or are used in TCM.<ref>http://www.koreantk.com/en/m_about/about_01.jsp?about=1</ref>
In Vietnam, traditional medicine comprises Thuoc Bac (Northern Medicine) and Thuoc Nam (Southern Medicine). Only those who can understand Chinese characters could diagnose and prescribe remedies in Northern Medicine. The theory of Northern Medicine is based on the Yin-Yang interactions and the eight trigrams, as used in Chinese Medicine.<ref>http://asiarecipe.com/vietmedicine.html</ref><ref>http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/10755530152639710</ref> Herbs such as [[Gleditsia sinensis]] are used in both Traditional Vietnamese Medicine and TCM.
[[Panax ginseng|Ginseng]] is the most broadly used substance for the most broad set of alleged cures. Powdered antlers, horns, teeth, and bones are second in importance to ginseng, with claims ranging from curing cancer to curing impotence.
== Mammals == === Human parts and excreta === {{main|Traditional Chinese medicines derived from the human body}} Human body parts and [[excreta]] are currently used in TCM medicines and are included in its new textbooks and handbooks, such as [[licorice]] in human [[feces]], dried human [[placenta]], finger nails, child's [[urine]], hair, and urinary sediments (''Hominis Urinae Sedimentum'', Ren Zhong Bai).<ref name=HDCM>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/0-306-46867-0_7 |chapter='Human Drugs' in Chinese Medicine and the Confucian View: An Interpretive Study |title=Confucian Bioethics |series=Philosophy and Medicine |year=2002 |last1=Nie |first1=Jing-Bao |isbn=0-7923-5723-X |volume=61 |pages=167–206}}</ref> The current consumption of human parts is considered [[cannibalism]] by some.<ref>Regenerative Medicine Using Pregnancy-Specific Biological Substances, Niranjan Bhattacharya, Phillip Stubblefield, ed, p.vi</ref> Other parts include [[pubic hair]], [[flesh]], [[blood]], [[bone]], [[semen]], and [[menstrual blood]].<ref name=HDCM/> The [[Bencao Gangmu]] describes the use of 35 human waste products and body parts as medicines, such as bones, fingernail, hairs, dandruff, earwax, impurities on the teeth, feces, urine, sweat, and organs. - Also listed are human [[breath]] and the "[[soul]] of criminals that were [[hanged]]", which is considered under TCM to be a material object resembling [[charcoal]] that is dug out of the ground beneath the body shortly after a hanged criminal died, but very few human or allegedly human products remain in use today.<ref name=HDCM/>
There is considerable controversy about the ethics of use of criminals for body parts, using humans as commodities, and consumption of human body parts which some consider to be [[cannibalism]].<ref name=HDCM/>
==== Dried human placenta ==== Dried human [[placenta]] is believed to treat [[male impotence]], male and female [[infertility]], chronic cough, [[asthma]], and [[insomnia]].<ref name=CHMFS>''Chinese Herbal Medicine: Formulas & Strategies'', Volker Scheid, Dan Bensky, Andrew Ellis, Randall Barolet</ref><ref name=CHMMM>''Chinese Herbal Medicine: Materia Medica'', Dan Bensky, Steven Clavey, Erich Stoger, Andrew Gamble, Lilian Lai Bensky</ref><ref name=ICMM>''An Illustrated Chinese Materia Medica'', Jing-Nuan Wu</ref><ref name=MMCM>''A Materia Medica for Chinese Medicine: plants, minerals and animal products'', Carl-Herman Hempen</ref><ref>''Ziheche'', [http://www.tcmtreatment.com/herbs/0-ziheche.htm TCM Treatment]</ref><ref name=TCMMMCR>''The Traditional Chinese Medicine Materia Medica Clinical Reference'', Peter Holmes (Author), Jing Wang (Author), Heather McIver</ref>
==== Human feces and urine ==== {{further|Probiotic}} {{further|Fecal transplant}} The contemporary use of [[licorice]] in prepared [[human feces]] is known as Ren Zhong Huang<ref>[http://healthytaoherbs.com/kb/tcm-herbs/ TCM Herb Master List, Healthy Tao Herbs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711155740/http://healthytaoherbs.com/kb/tcm-herbs/ |date=2011-07-11 }}</ref> Human urine sediment is called Ren Zhong Bai. Both Ren Zhong Huang and Ren Zhong Bai are used to treat inflammatory conditions and [[Mycosis|fungal infections]] of the skin and mouth.<ref>"The Treatment of 75 Cases of Pediatric Oral Thrush with the Sweet, Cold, Protecting Yin Method" by Wang Le-ping, Shang Hai Zhong Yi Yao Za Zhi (The Shanghai Journal of Chinese Medicine & Medicinals), #5, 1994, p. 22, {{cite web |url=http://www.bluepoppy.com/cfwebstorefb/images/features/rr_45.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708074039/http://www.bluepoppy.com/cfwebstorefb/images/features/rr_45.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref>
In Traditional Chinese medicine, human feces is used in a decoction of licorice. These feces-licorice decoctions have been found to have profound differences in [[pharmacokinetics]] as compared to pure [[glycyrrhizin]].<ref>Profound difference of metabolic pharmacokinetics between pure glycyrrhizin and [[glycyrrhizin]] in licorice decoction, Yu-Chi Houa, Su-Lan Hsiub, Hui Chingc, Ya-Tze Lind, e, Shang-Yuan Tsaib, Kuo-Ching Wenf and Pei-Dawn Lee Chao, Life Sciences Volume 76, Issue 10, 21 January 2005, Pages 1167-1176, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T99-4F011GK-1&_user=10&_coverDate=01%2F21%2F2005&_rdoc=1&_fmt=high&_orig=gateway&_origin=gateway&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_searchStrId=1675307294&_rerunOrigin=scholar.google&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=f44f7f21c8fc6cdf6b4fdb965173348f&searchtype=a]</ref> Initial studies investigating traditional Chinese Medicine indicate that taking the fecal bacteria alongside the licorice may improve the [[pharmacokinetics]] of glycyrrhizin,<ref>Protective effect of irisolidone, a metabolite of kakkalide, against hydrogen peroxide induced cell damage via antioxidant effect, Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry, Volume 16, Issue 3, 1 February 2008, Pages 1133-1141, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6TF8-4R17TTX-2&_user=10&_coverDate=02%2F01%2F2008&_rdoc=1&_fmt=high&_orig=gateway&_origin=gateway&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_searchStrId=1675234576&_rerunOrigin=scholar.google&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=73f7ea6b1c94e32d408c8606a342cea3&searchtype=a]</ref> and certain strains of gut bacteria may produce an anti-tumor effect and an immune boosting effect.<ref>PRELIMINARARY RESEARCH ON THE ANTITUMOR EFFECT AND IMMUNOLOGICAL EFFECT OF BIFIDOBACTERIUM ADOLESCENTIS DM8504 STRAIN ON THE MOUSE WITH HEPATOCARCINOMA, Yi Qing;et al , CHINESE JOURNAL OF MICROECOLOGY, CHINESE JOURNAL OF MICROECOLOGY, 1996-02, [http://en.cnki.com.cn/Article_en/CJFDTOTAL-ZGWS602.001.htm]</ref> Human [[gut flora]] may protect against cell damage caused by hydrogen peroxide.<ref>''"In traditional Chinese medicine… 0.5 g fresh human feces in a ... volume of 100ml of anaerobic dilution medium"'', ''Protective effect of irisolidone, a metabolite of kakkalide, against hydrogen peroxide induced cell damage via antioxidant effect'', Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry, Volume 16, Issue 3, 1 February 2008, Pages 1133-1141 , Kyoung Ah Kanga, Rui Zhanga, Mei Jing Piaoa, Dong Ok Koa, Zhi Hong Wanga, Bum Joon Kim</ref>
==== Human penis ==== {{Quote|''The human penis is not a drug''|author=[[Li Shizhen]]}} [[Human penis]] is believed under TCM to stop bleeding, and as with other TCM medicines, the basis for belief in its therapeutic effects is anecdotal and not based on the [[scientific method]]; [[Li Shizhen]], author of the greatest pharmacological work in pre-modern China, the [[Bencao Gangmu]], objected to use of human penis, but cited the anecdotal evidence and included it in the [[Bencao Gangmu]], which is still a standard reference today.<ref name=HDCM/><ref>How scientific is the science in ethnopharmacology? Historical perspectives and epistemological problems, Journal of Ethnopharmacology, Volume 122, Issue 2, 18 March 2009, Pages 177-183, Jürg Gertsch</ref>
==== Human pubic hair ==== [[pubic hair|Human pubic hair]] ("shady hair") was claimed to cure snakebite, difficult birth, abnormal urination, and "yin and yang disorder" (A disease unique to TCM based on its views of sexual behavior).<ref name=HDCM/>
===Donkey-hide gelatin=== [[Donkey-hide gelatin|Gelatin made from the hide of donkeys]] (ejiao) is made into pellets for use in making teas.<ref name=LICHT>''Lethal Ingestion of Chinese Herbal Tea Containing Ch'an Su'', Western Journal of Medicine, 1996 January; 164(1, pp. 71–75, R J Ko, M S Greenwald, S M Loscutoff, A M Au, B R Appel, R A Kreutzer, W F Haddon, T Y Jackson, F O Boo, and G Presicek, [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1303306/pdf/westjmed00352-0073.pdf]</ref>
=== Deer penis === {{Main|Deer penis wine}} Deer penis is commonly sold in Chinese pharmacies.<ref>''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'', Volume 274, Atlantic Monthly Co., 1994</ref> and served in specialized restaurants such as the [[Guo Li Zhuang]] restaurant in [[Beijing]].<ref name=telegraph>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/1510756/On-the-menu-today-horse-penis-and-testicles-with-a-chilli-dip.html Richard Spencer, On the menu today: horse penis and testicles with a chilli dip, The Telegraph]</ref> The deer penis is typically very large and, under TCM it must be extracted from the deer whilst still alive.<ref name="Angang">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pwu0bFjopW0C&pg=PA98&dq=Deer+penis&hl=en&ei=xP4hTPy1LYmXsQaUxvHlBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Deer%20penis&f=false|author=Stafford, Charles|title=The roads of Chinese childhood: learning and identification in Angang|work=Volume 97 of Cambridge studies in social and cultural anthropology|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|page=98|year=1995|isbn=0-521-46574-5}}</ref> Often it is then sliced into small pieces, typically by women and then roasted and dried in the sun and then preserved while the deer looks on.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} China banned deer penis wine during the [[2008 Summer Olympics]], as it is believed that the wine is an effective treatment for athletic injuries.<ref>{{cite web|author=Harding, Andrew|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/5371500.stm|title=Beijing's penis emporium|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=September 23, 2006|accessdate=June 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aCQ0IoTLiM.4&refer=home|title=Deer Penis Loses Favor as China's Olympians Fear Drug Testers |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=March 23, 2008|accessdate=June 23, 2010}}</ref>
=== Flying squirrel feces === [[Flying squirrel]] [[feces]] is used to stop bleeding.<ref name=CHMFS/><ref name=CHMMM/><ref name=ICMM/><ref name=MMCM/><ref name=TCMMMCR/>
The text ''Chinese Medical Herbology and Pharmacology'' notes that flying squirrel feces has a ''"distinct odor"'' that ''"may decrease patient compliance"'' with ingesting it.<ref name=CMHP>Chinese Medical Herbology and Pharmacology, John Chen and Tina Chen, Art of Medicine Press, {{ISBN|0-9740635-0-9}}, [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0974063509#_]</ref>
It is believed to have uses for amenorrhea, menses pain, postpartum abdominal pain, epigastric pain, and chest pain.<ref name=CHMMM/> It is boiled in a decoction with other herbs prior to ingestion. If it is to be used in a formula to stop heavy bleeding; it is dry fried prior to making the decoction.<ref name=CHMFS/><ref name=CHMMM/><ref name=ICMM/><ref name=MMCM/><ref name=TCMMMCR/><ref name="Herbal Database, Wu Ling Zhi">[http://www.yinyanghouse.com/theory/herbalmedicine/wu_ling_zhi_tcm_herbal_database ''Herbal Database'', Wu Ling Zhi]</ref> Use of flying squirrel feces as medicine has been associated with ''[[Rickettsia]]'' infections.<ref>''Flying Squirrel – Associated Typhus'', Infectious Diseases, 2003, Mary G. Reynolds, John W. Krebs, James A. Comer, John W. Sumner, Thomas C. Rushton, Carlos E. Lopez, William L. Nicholson, Jane A. Rooney, Susan E. Lance-Parker, Jennifer H. McQuiston, Christopher D. Paddock, James E. Childs</ref>
=== Pangolin scales === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} Scales of [[pangolin]]s are used in traditional Chinese medicine. [https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2015/08/18/432568915/the-worlds-most-trafficked-mammal-is-one-you-may-never-have-heard-of]
=== Rhinoceros horn === The [[Rhinoceros#Horn trade and use|horn of a rhinoceros]] is used as an [[antipyretic]] - because it is believed to "cool the blood" - however several scientific studies failed to find any active [[antipyretic]] [[molecule]] in rhinoceros horn.<ref name=FTCMRH>''Facts about traditional Chinese medicine (TCM): rhinoceros horn'', Encucolpedia Britanica, [http://www.britannica.com/facts/5/1035448/traditional-Chinese-medicine-TCM-as-discussed-in-rhinoceros-mammal]</ref> The illegal trade in rhinoceros horns has decimated the world's rhino population by more than 90 percent over the past 40 years.<ref name=RH>''"Rhino horn: All myth, no medicine"'', ''National Geographic'', Rhishja Larson</ref>
=== Tiger penis === {{Main|Tiger penis}}
The penis and testicles of male tigers is used by some to treat [[erectile dysfunction]] and to improve sexual performance, despite tiger penis being a [[placebo]].<ref>[http://www.tigerhomes.org/animal/tiger-penis.cfm "Aphrodisiacs and the Myth of Tiger Penis Magical Cures"], ''Tigerhomes.org''</ref> Critically endangered species such as the [[Sumatran tiger]] are often being hunted to keep up with the illegal demand for tiger parts.<ref name="2008 report from TRAFFIC">[http://www.traffic.org/home/2008/2/13/tiger-tiger-future-not-so-bright.html 2008 report from TRAFFIC]</ref>
== Reptiles and amphibians == === Snake oil === {{Main|Snake oil}} {{Further|Eicosapentaenoic acid}} Snake oil is the most widely known Chinese medicine in the west, due to extensive marketing in the west in the late 1800s and early 1900s, and wild claims of its efficacy to treat many maladies.<ref name=SOWJM>''Snake Oil'', Western Journal of Medicine, Aug 1989;151(2):208, R. A. Kunin</ref><ref name=FHFK>''Fats that Heal: Fats that Kill'', Udo Erasmus, 1993, {{ISBN|0-920470-38-6}}</ref> Snake oil is a traditional Chinese medicine used to treat joint pain by rubbing it on joints as a [[liniment]].<ref name=SOWJM/>
This is theoretically possible because snake oil is higher in [[eicosapentaenoic acid]] than most other oils. But there are no scientific studies showing that rubbing it on joints has any positive effect, or that snake oil is safe for daily consumption.<ref name=SOWJM/><ref name=FHFK/>
=== Toad secretions === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} The secretions of various species of [[bufo|toads]] are an ingredient in certain traditional Chinese teas. However, these teas may contain deadly amounts of [[cardiac glycosides]] and thus should be avoided<ref name=LICHT/>
=== Toad-headed gecko === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} [[Phrynocephalus|Toad-head gecko]]s are gutted, beheaded, dried and then crushed, and are used to treat [[asthma]], [[male impotence]] and the [[common cold]].<ref>[http://www.nutritionalwellness.com/nutrition/herbs/g/gecko.php Gecko, Ntritional Wellness]</ref>
=== Turtle shell === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} Widespread medicinal use of [[turtle shell]]s is of concern to conservationists.<ref name=guiban>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.2744/CCB-0747.1 |journal= Chelonian Conservation and Biology|volume= 8|issue=1|pages=11–18|year= 2009|doi= 10.2744/CCB-0747.1 |title=Unregulated Trade in Turtle Shells for Chinese Traditional Medicine in East and Southeast Asia: The Case of Taiwan |first1=Tien-Hsi|last1=Chen1|first2= Hsien-Cheh|last2= Chang2|first3= Kuang-Yang|last3= Lue|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
== Marine life == === Seahorse ===
[[Seahorse]] (''Hai Ma'') is a fundamental ingredient in therapies for a variety of disorders, including asthma, [[arteriosclerosis]], incontinence, impotence, insomnia, thyroid disorders, skin ailments, broken bones, heart disease, throat infections, abdominal pain, sores, skin infections; it is also used as an aphrodisiac and to facilitate childbirth.<ref name="Pbs.org">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/seahorse/vincent.html |title=NOVA Online | Kingdom of the Seahorse | Amanda Vincent |publisher=Pbs.org |date= |accessdate=2009-12-07}}</ref><ref>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/sea_horse.php ''Sea Horse''], Acupuncture Today.</ref> As many as 20 million seahorses per year may be used for TCM purposes.<ref>[http://advocacy.britannica.com/blog/advocacy/2007/10/traditional-chinese-medicine-and-endangered-animals/ ''Traditional Chinese Medicine and Endangered Animals''], Encyclopædia Britannica Advocacy for Animals.</ref><ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/seahorse/vincent.html "Seahorse Crusader Amanda Vincent"] on ''Nova'' television show</ref> In one study, 58 seahorse samples were collected from various TCM vendors in Taiwan, and of all the eight species identified from the fifty-eight samples, seven were vulnerable, and one was endangered.<ref>Chang ''et al,'' [http://www.jfda-online.com/article/S1021-9498(13)00043-4/abstract ''Authenticating the use of dried seahorses in the traditional Chinese medicine market in Taiwan using molecular forensics''], Journal of Food and Drug Analysis Volume 21, Issue 3 , Pages 310-316, September 2013.</ref>
=== Shark fin soup === {{main|Shark fin soup}} Shark fin soup is traditionally regarded as beneficial for health in East Asia, and its status as an elite dish has led to huge demand with the increase of affluence in China, devastating shark populations.<ref name="Sfgate.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/g/archive/2003/01/20/urbananimal.DTL |title=Shark Fin Soup: An Eco-Catastrophe? |publisher=Sfgate.com |date=2003-01-20 |accessdate=2009-12-07}}</ref>
== Insects == === Blister beetle === {{main|Cantharidin}} [[Blister beetle]]s (Ban mao) are believed under TCM to treat skin lesions, because they cause them.<ref name=ESTC>An Effective Supplemental Therapy for Cancer, Acupuncture Today, February, 2010, Vol. 11, Issue 02, Haitao Cao</ref> They contain the [[blister agent]] [[cantharidin]].<ref name=IDCD>''Insect derived crude drugs in the Chinese song dynasty'', Namba Tsuneo, MA Yong-Hua, Inagaki Kenji, Journal of Ethnopharmacology, Volume 24, Issues 2-3, December 1988, Pages 247-285, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T8D-475NV3V-6S&_user=10&_coverDate=12%2F31%2F1988&_rdoc=1&_fmt=high&_orig=gateway&_origin=gateway&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_searchStrId=1667183354&_rerunOrigin=scholar.google&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=e9c15c0628afe99e4a22851291e1dca9&searchtype=a]</ref>
=== Centipede === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} Powdered centipede (wu gong) is believed under TCM to treat [[tetanus]], seizures, convulsions, skin lesions, and pain.<ref name=CAT>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/centipede.php Centipede, Acupuncture Today]</ref> It is toxic.<ref name=CAT/>
=== Hornets nest === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} Hornets nest (lu feng fang) is used to treat skin disorders and ringworm.<ref>[http://tcm.health-info.org/Herbology.Materia.Medica/lufengfangproperties.htm Lu Feng Fang, Materia Metrica]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It may be toxic.<ref name=IDCD/>
=== Leech === [[Hirudo medicinalis]] is used in TCM to treat [[amenorrhea]], abdominal and chest pain, and constipation.<ref name=LAT>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/leech.php Leech, Acupuncture Today]</ref>
=== Scorpion === Dried scorpions (Chinese: 全蠍, Pinyin:''quan xie'') may be ground into a powder and mixed with water.<ref name=SAT/> In TCM, powdered scorpion is toxic and is therefore used to treat poisoning.<ref name=SAT>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/scorpion.php Scorpion, Acupuncture Todady]</ref> A scorpion venom [[peptide]] was found to help with [[arthritis]] [[in vitro]].<ref>http://www.news.harvard.edu/gazette/2004/01.08/01-scorpion.html</ref>
==Fungi== Various [[fungi]] are used in TCM. Some may have scientifically proven medicinal value, while others may be extremely toxic.
=== Supernatural mushroom === {{Main|Ganoderma lucidum}} The [[supernatural]] mushroom ([[lingzhi mushroom]], Chinese "linh chi" = "supernatural mushroom", "[[reishi mushroom]]" in Japan) encompasses several [[fungal]] species of the [[Genus (biology)|genus]] ''[[Ganoderma]]'', and most commonly refers to the closely related species, ''Ganoderma lucidum'' and ''[[Ganoderma tsugae]]''. ''G. lucidum'' enjoys special veneration in [[East Asia]], where it has been used as a [[medicinal mushroom]] in traditional Chinese medicine for more than 2,000 years,<ref>Jones, Kenneth (1990), ''Reishi: Ancient Herb for Modern Times'', Sylvan Press, p. 6.</ref> making it one of the oldest mushrooms known to have been used medicinally. Today, the ling zhi mushroom is used in a herbal formula designed to minimize the side effects of chemotherapy.<ref name="maciociaonline.blogspot.sg">http://maciociaonline.blogspot.sg/2012_05_01_archive.html</ref>
Extracts of the [[Ganoderma lucidum|mushroom]] are used as a commercial pharmaceutical to suppress cancer cell proliferation and migration, although the mechanisms by which this is achieved are currently unknown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lsb380.plbio.lsu.edu/Highway%20markers%20folder/Ganoderma.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121214205245/http://lsb380.plbio.lsu.edu/Highway%20markers%20folder/Ganoderma.html |archivedate=2012-12-14 |df= }}</ref>
===''Tremella fuciformis'' === ''[[Tremella fuciformis]]'' is used as a beauty product by women in China and Japan as it reportedly increases moisture retention in the skin and prevents senile degradation of micro-blood vessels in the skin, reducing wrinkles and smoothing fine lines. Other beneficial effects come from its ability to increase the activity of [[superoxide dismutase|SOD]] in the brain and liver.<ref name="Reshetnikov 2000"/><ref name="Reshetnikov 2000">{{cite journal |vauthors=Reshetnikov SV, Wasser SP, Duckman I, Tsukor K |title=Medicinal value of the genus ''Tremella'' Pers. (Heterobasidiomycetes) (review) |journal=International Journal of Medicinal Mushrooms |year=2000 |volume=2 |issue=3 |pages=345–67 |doi=10.1615/IntJMedMushr.v2.i3.10}}</ref>
== Plants == There are thousands of [[plant]]s that are used as medicines.<ref name="ReferenceB">Chinese Medical Herbology and Pharmacology, by John K. Chen, Tina T. Chen</ref> The following list represents a very small portion of the TCM pharmacopoeia.
===Aconite=== [[Monkshood]] root is commonly used in TCM.<ref>''"Aconitum in Traditional Chinese, Medicine—A valuable drug or an unpredictable risk?"'', ''Journal of Ethnopharmacology'', Volume 126, Issue 1, 29 October 2009, Judith Singhuber, Ming Zhu, Sonja Prinz, Brigitte Kopp, Pages 18-30</ref> It was once so commonly used it was called "the king of the 100 herbs".<ref name=YTHF>Yang Tianhui: Notes from My Visit to the Fuzi Growing Area of Zhangming County (Song Dynasty, 1099 CE), , Heiner Fruehauf, {{cite web |url=http://www.classicalchinesemedicine.org/2010/12/yang-tianhui-notes-from-my-visit-to-the-fuzi-growing-area-of-zhangming-county-song-dynasty-1099-ce/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317112442/http://www.classicalchinesemedicine.org/2010/12/yang-tianhui-notes-from-my-visit-to-the-fuzi-growing-area-of-zhangming-county-song-dynasty-1099-ce/ |archivedate=2011-03-17 |df= }}</ref><ref name=IOA>[http://www.classicalchinesemedicine.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/fruehauf_fuziinterview1.pdf ''"The Importance of Aconite (fuzi)"''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725175628/http://www.classicalchinesemedicine.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/fruehauf_fuziinterview1.pdf |date=2011-07-25 }}</ref>
The [[monkshood]] plant contains what is called "the queen of poisons", the highly toxic [[alkaloid]] [[aconitine]].<ref name="pmid19514874">{{cite journal |author=Chan TY |title=Aconite poisoning |journal=Clinical Toxicology |volume=47 |issue=4 |pages=279–85 |date=April 2009 |pmid=19514874 |doi=10.1080/15563650902904407 |url=}}</ref> [[Aconitine]] is easily absorbed through the skin, eyes and through the lining of the nose; Death may occur through respiratory paralysis. A few minutes after exposure, [[paresthesia]] starts at the mouth and slowly beings to cover the whole body, [[Anesthesia]], hot and cold flashes, nausea and vomiting and other similar symptoms follow. Sometimes there is strong pain, accompanied by cramps, or diarrhea.<ref>{{aut|Roth, L., Daunderer, M. & Kormann, K.}} (1994): ''Giftpflanzen - Pflanzengifte''. {{ISBN|3-933203-31-7}}.</ref>
When a person has a negative reaction to the alkaloid, some practitioners of classical Chinese medicine think that this is because it was that the monkshood plant was processed incorrectly or planted on the wrong place or on the wrong day of the year; Not because of an [[drug overdose|overdose]]<ref name=IOA/><ref name=PZ>Pao Zhi: An Introduction to the Use of Processed Chinese Medicinals, Philippe Sionneau</ref>
The Chinese also used [[aconitine]] both for hunting<ref>Sung, Ying-hsing. ''T’ien kung k’ai wu''. Sung Ying-hsing. 1637. Published as ''Chinese Technology in the seventeenth century''. Translated and annotated by E-tu Zen Sun and Shiou-chuan Sun. 1996. Mineola. New York. Dover Publications, p. 267.</ref> and for warfare.<ref>Chavannes, Édouard. "Trois Généraux Chinois de la dynastie des Han Orientaux. Pan Tch’ao (32-102 p.C.); – son fils Pan Yong; – Leang K’in (112 p.C.). Chapitre LXXVII du Heou Han chou.". 1906. ''T’oung pao'' 7, pp. 226-227.</ref>
===Birthworts=== {{further|Aristolochic acid}} {{Further|Birthwort}} [[Aristolochiaceae|Birthworts]] (family Aristolochiaceae) are often used to treat many aliments, including hypertension, hemorrhoids, and colic.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tcm.health-info.org/Herbology.Materia.Medica/madouling-properties.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213113633/http://tcm.health-info.org/Herbology.Materia.Medica/madouling-properties.htm |archivedate=2012-02-13 |df= }}</ref> However - they are of little medicinal value and contain the [[carcinogen]] [[aristolochic acid]].<ref>http://www.fda.gov/Food/RecallsOutbreaksEmergencies/SafetyAlertsAdvisories/ucm096374.htm</ref> The over-use of this plant family in TCM is thought be a significant cause of upper urinary tract cancer and kidney failure in Taiwan; in 2012, approximately a third of all herbal prescriptions in Taiwan contained AA. Supplements containing AA may be responsible for [[Balkan endemic nephropathy|BEN]].<ref name=taiwan>C.-H. Chen, K. G. Dickman, M. Moriya, J. Zavadil, V. S. Sidorenko, K. L. Edwards, D. V. Gnatenko, L. Wu, R. J. Turesky, X.-R. Wu, Y.-S. Pu, A. P. Grollman. [http://www.pnas.org/content/109/21/8241 ''Aristolochic acid-associated urothelial cancer in Taiwan'']. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 2012; DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1119920109</ref>
=== ''Camellia sinensis'' === [[Tea]] from India, Sri Lanka, Java and Japan is used in TCM for aches and pains, digestion, depression, detoxification, as an energizer and, to prolong life.<ref>''"The distribution of minerals and flavonoids in the tea plant ([[Camellia sinensis]])"'', ''Il Farmaco'', Volume 56, Issues 5-7, 1 July 2001, Lydia Ferrara, Domenico Montesanoa, and Alfonso Senatore, Pages 397-401</ref>
===Cayenne pepper=== {{expand section|date=September 2015}} [[Cayenne pepper]] is believed under TCM to be a prophylactic medicine.<ref>[http://www.umm.edu/altmed/articles/cayenne--000230.htm]</ref>
=== Chinese cucumber === The fruit of ''[[Trichosanthes kirilowii]]'' is believed to treat tumors, reduce fevers, swelling and coughing, abscesses, amenorrhea, jaundice, and polyuria. The plant is deadly if improperly prepared; causing [[pulmonary edema]], [[cerebral hemorrhage]], seizures, and high fever.<ref>[https://www.drugs.com/npp/chinese-cucumber.html Chinese Cucumber, Drugs.com]</ref>
=== Chrysanthemum flowers === [[Chrysanthemum]] flowers (Ju Hua) are used in TCM to treat headaches, fever, dizziness and dry eyes. They are also used to make certain beverages. Chrysanthemum flowers are believed to "brighten the eyes, pacify the liver, break blood, clear heat, stop dysentery, disperse wind, relieve toxicity, and regulate the center".<ref>http://www.koreantk.com/servlet/MedicDetailServlet?cmd=1&med_cd=M0000050&searchGbn=medic&ctrllist=undefined&pagesize=undefined&sorder=undefined&view_type=eng&langType=E</ref>
=== Cocklebur fruit === Cocklebur fruit (''[[Xanthium]]'', cang er zi) is one of the most important herbs in TCM, and is commonly to treat sinus congestion, chronic nasal obstructions and discharges, and respiratory allergies.<ref>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/xanthium.php Xanthium, Acupuncture Today]</ref>
The plant is mildly toxic and can cause [[gastrointestinal]] upset<ref>Toxicological Risks of Chinese Herbs, Planta Med 2010; 76(17): 2012-2018, Debbie Shaw, [https://www.thieme-connect.com/ejournals/abstract/plantamedica/doi/10.1055/s-0030-1250533]</ref>
=== Crow dipper === ''[[Pinellia ternata]]'' is believed under TCM to be the strongest of all TCM herbs for removing phlegm. {{Citation needed|date=September 2015}}
Active ingredinets of this herb include: [[methionine]], [[glycine]], [[Beta-Aminobutyric acid|β-aminobutyric acid]], [[GABA|γ-aminobutyric acid]], [[ephedrine]], [[trigonelline]], [[phytosterols]] and [[glucoronic acid]].<ref name="maciociaonline.blogspot.sg"/>
Care should be taken as crow dipper is toxic. {{Citation needed|date=September 2015}}
=== Croton seed === Seeds of ''[[Croton tiglium]]'' are used in TCM to treat gastrointestinal disorders, convulsions, and skin lesions. They are often used with rhubarb, dried ginger and apricot seed.<ref>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/croton_seed.php Croton Seed, Acupuncture Today]</ref> Care should be taken as the seeds are toxic and [[carcinogenic]].<ref>Predictive and preventive toxicology of innovative industrial crops of the spurge (Euphorbiaceae) family, Gminski, Richard; Hecker, Erich, [[Interdisciplinary Science Reviews]], Volume 23, Number 2, June 1998 , pp. 99-112(14), []</ref>
=== Dioscorea root === {{confusing section|date=September 2015}} In TCM, Dioscorea Root (Radix Dioscorea, ''Huai Shan Yao'' or ''Shan Yao'' in Chinese), benefits both the ''Yin'' and ''Yang'', and is used to ''tonify'' the lungs, spleen and kidney. It can "be used in large amounts and 30g is suggested when treating diabetes". If taken habitually, it "brightens the intellect and prolongs life".<ref name="chineseherbacademy.org">http://www.chineseherbacademy.org/articles/dm2.shtml</ref>
=== Ginger === {{main|Ginger}} [[Ginger|Ginger root, ''Zingiber officinale'']], has been used in China for over 2,000 years to treat indigestion, upset stomach, diarrhea, and nausea. It is also used in TCM to treat arthritis, colic, diarrhea, heart conditions, the common cold, flu-like symptoms, headaches, and [[menstrual cramp]]s. Today, health care professionals worldwide commonly recommend ginger to help prevent or treat nausea and vomiting associated with motion sickness, pregnancy, and cancer chemotherapy. It is also used as a treatment for minor stomach upset, as a supplement for [[arthritis]], and may even help prevent heart disease and cancer.<ref>[http://www.umm.edu/altmed/articles/ginger-000246.htm ''Ginger'', University of Maryland Medical Center]</ref>
=== Ginkgo === {{main|Ginkgo biloba}} ''[[Ginkgo biloba]]'' seeds are crushed and believed under TCM to treat [[asthma]].<ref>[http://www.tcmbasics.com/materiamedica/semen_ginkgo.htm Ginkgo, TCM Basics]</ref> ''G. biloba'' has been used by humans for nearly 5,000 years.<ref name= GBA/> However, further scientific studies are needed to establish the efficacy of ''G. biloba'' as a medicine.<ref name= GBA>Dubey AK, Shankar PR, Upadhyaya D, Deshpande VY. Ginkgo biloba--an appraisal. Kathmandu University Medical Journal. 2004 Jul-Sep; 2(3): 225-9</ref>
=== Ginseng === {{Further|Panax ginseng}}
[[Ginseng]] root is the most widely sold traditional Chinese medicine. The name "ginseng" is used to refer to both American (''[[Panax quinquefolius]]'') and Asian or Korean ginseng (''[[Panax ginseng|P. ginseng]]''), which belong to the species Panax and have a similar chemical makeup. Siberian ginseng or Eleuthero (''[[Eleutherococcus senticosus]]'') is another type of plant. Asian ginseng has a light tan, gnarled root that often looks like a human body with stringy shoots for arms and legs. In ancient times, herbalists thought that because of the way ginseng looks it could treat many different kinds of syndromes, from fatigue and stress to asthma and cancer. In traditional Chinese medicine, ginseng was often combined with other herbs and used often to bring longevity, strength, and mental alacrity to its users. Asian ginseng is believed to enhance the immune system in preventing and treating infection and disease. Several clinical studies report that Asian ginseng can improve immune function. Studies have found that ginseng seems to increase the number of immune cells in the blood, and improve the immune system's response to a flu vaccine. In one study, 227 participants received either ginseng or placebo for 12 weeks, with a flu shot administered after 4 weeks. The number of colds and flu were two-thirds lower in the group that took ginseng.<ref>[http://www.umm.edu/altmed/articles/asian-ginseng-000249.htm]</ref>
Ginseng contains stimulants, but may produce side effect including [[Hypertension|high blood pressure]], [[Hypotension|low blood pressure]], and [[mastalgia]].<ref>[http://www.aafp.org/afp/20031015/1539.html http://www.aafp.org/afp/20031015/1539.html]</ref> Ginseng may also lead to induction of [[mania]] in depressed patients who mix it with antidepressants.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fugh-Berman|first=Adriane |title=Herb-drug interactions|journal=The Lancet|volume=355|issue=9198|pages=134–138|issn=|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B6T1B-41CNTJ6-T/2/5571af69320b04517be500e5704b99c1|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(99)06457-0|year=2000|pmid=10675182}}</ref> One of the most common and characteristic symptoms of acute overdose of ginseng from the genus ''[[Panax]]'' is bleeding. Symptoms of mild overdose with ''Panax'' ginseng may include dry mouth and lips, excitation, fidgeting, irritability, tremor, palpitations, blurred vision, headache, insomnia, increased body temperature, increased blood pressure, edema, decreased appetite, increased sexual desire, dizziness, itching, eczema, early morning diarrhea, bleeding, and fatigue.<ref name=CMHP/> Symptoms of gross overdose with ''Panax'' ginseng may include nausea, vomiting, irritability, restlessness, urinary and bowel incontinence, fever, increased blood pressure, increased respiration, decreased sensitivity and reaction to light, decreased heart rate, cyanotic facial complexion, red face, seizures, convulsions, and delirium.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
The constituents of ginseng include triterpene saponins, aglycone protopanaxadiol, aglycone protopanaxytriol, aglycone oleanolic acid and water-soluble polysaccharides.<ref name="maciociaonline.blogspot.sg"/>
=== Goji berry === {{main|Wolfberry}} Marketing literature for [[goji berry]] ([[wolfberry]]) products including several "goji juices" suggest that wolfberry [[polysaccharides]] have extensive biological effects and health benefits, although none of these claims have been supported by peer-reviewed research.
A May 2008 clinical study published by the peer-reviewed [[Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine]] indicated that [[parameter|parametric]] data, including body weight, did not show significant differences between subjects receiving ''Lycium barbarum'' berry juice and subjects receiving the placebo; the study concluded that subjective measures of health were improved and suggested further research in humans was necessary.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Amagase H, Nance DM |title=A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, clinical study of the general effects of a standardized Lycium barbarum (Goji) Juice, GoChi |journal=J Altern Complement Med |volume=14 |issue=4 |pages=403–12 |date=May 2008 |pmid=18447631 |doi=10.1089/acm.2008.0004 |url=}}</ref> This study, however, was subject to a variety of criticisms concerning its experimental design and interpretations.<ref>{{cite web | author=Daniells S.| title = Questions raised over Goji science.| publisher = NutraIngredients.com-USA| url = http://www.nutraingredients-usa.com/Research/Questions-raised-over-Goji-science |date=October 2008 }}</ref>
Published studies have also reported possible medicinal benefits of ''Lycium barbarum'', especially due to its antioxidant properties,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wu SJ, Ng LT, Lin CC |title=Antioxidant activities of some common ingredients of traditional Chinese medicine, Angelica sinensis, Lycium barbarum and Poria cocos |journal=Phytother Res |volume=18 |issue=12 |pages=1008–12 |date=December 2004 |pmid=15742346 |doi=10.1002/ptr.1617 |url=}}</ref> including potential benefits against cardiovascular and inflammatory diseases,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jia YX, Dong JW, Wu XX, Ma TM, Shi AY |title=[The effect of lycium barbarum polysaccharide on vascular tension in two-kidney, one clip model of hypertension] |language=Chinese |journal=Sheng Li Xue Bao |volume=50 |issue=3 |pages=309–14 |date=June 1998 |pmid=11324572 |doi= |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Luo Q, Li Z, Huang X, Yan J, Zhang S, Cai YZ |title=Lycium barbarum polysaccharides: Protective effects against heat-induced damage of rat testes and H2O2-induced DNA damage in mouse testicular cells and beneficial effect on sexual behavior and reproductive function of hemicastrated rats |journal=Life Sci. |volume=79 |issue=7 |pages=613–21 |date=July 2006 |pmid=16563441 |doi=10.1016/j.lfs.2006.02.012 |url=}}</ref> vision-related diseases<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cheng CY, Chung WY, Szeto YT, Benzie IF |title=Fasting plasma zeaxanthin response to Fructus barbarum L. (wolfberry; Kei Tze) in a food-based human supplementation trial |journal=Br. J. Nutr. |volume=93 |issue=1 |pages=123–30 |date=January 2005 |pmid=15705234 |doi= 10.1079/BJN20041284|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/abstract_S0007114505000188}}</ref> (such as age-related [[macular degeneration]] and [[glaucoma]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chan HC, Chang RC, Koon-Ching Ip A, etal |title=Neuroprotective effects of Lycium barbarum Lynn on protecting retinal ganglion cells in an ocular hypertension model of glaucoma |journal=Exp. Neurol. |volume=203 |issue=1 |pages=269–73 |date=January 2007 |pmid=17045262 |doi=10.1016/j.expneurol.2006.05.031 |url=}}</ref>), having neuroprotective properties<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Yu MS, Leung SK, Lai SW, etal |title=Neuroprotective effects of anti-aging oriental medicine Lycium barbarum against beta-amyloid peptide neurotoxicity |journal=Exp. Gerontol. |volume=40 |issue=8-9 |pages=716–27 |year=2005 |pmid=16139464 |doi=10.1016/j.exger.2005.06.010 |url=}}</ref> or as an anticancer<ref name="Gan L, Hua Zhang S, Liang Yang X, Bi Xu H 2004 563–9">{{cite journal |vauthors=Gan L, Hua Zhang S, Liang Yang X, Bi Xu H |title=Immunomodulation and antitumor activity by a polysaccharide-protein complex from Lycium barbarum |journal=Int. Immunopharmacol. |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=563–9 |date=April 2004 |pmid=15099534 |doi=10.1016/j.intimp.2004.01.023 |url=}}</ref> and [[immunomodulator]]y agent.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=He YL, Ying Y, Xu YL, Su JF, Luo H, Wang HF |title=[Effects of Lycium barbarum polysaccharide on tumor microenvironment T-lymphocyte subsets and dendritic cells in H22-bearing mice] |language=Chinese |journal=Zhong Xi Yi Jie He Xue Bao |volume=3 |issue=5 |pages=374–7 |date=September 2005 |pmid=16159572 |doi= 10.3736/jcim20050511|url=http://www.jcimjournal.com/en/showAbstrPage.aspx?articleid=428}}</ref>
Wolfberry leaves may be used to make tea, together with ''[[Boxthorn|Lycium]]'' root bark (called ''dìgǔpí''; [[wikt:地|地]] [[wikt:骨|骨]] [[wikt:皮|皮]] in Chinese), for traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). A glucopyranoside isolated from wolfberry root bark have inhibitory activity [[in vitro]] against human pathogenic [[bacteria]] and [[fungi]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lee DG, Park Y, Kim MR, etal |title=Anti-fungal effects of phenolic amides isolated from the root bark of Lycium chinense |journal=Biotechnol. Lett. |volume=26 |issue=14 |pages=1125–30 |date=July 2004 |pmid=15266117 |doi=10.1023/B:BILE.0000035483.85790.f7 |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lee DG, Jung HJ, Woo ER |title=Antimicrobial property of (+)-lyoniresinol-3alpha-O-beta-D-glucopyranoside isolated from the root bark of Lycium chinense Miller against human pathogenic microorganisms |journal=Arch. Pharm. Res. |volume=28 |issue=9 |pages=1031–6 |date=September 2005 |pmid=16212233 |doi= 10.1007/BF02977397|url=}}</ref>
=== Horny goat weed === {{further|Icariin}} {{further|PDE5 inhibitor}} [[Horny goat weed]] (Yin Yang Huo, 淫羊藿) may have use in treating [[erectile dysfunction]].<ref>[http://altmedicine.about.com/od/herbsupplementguide/a/HornyGoatWeed.htm Horny Goat Weed, Altmedicine.com]</ref> Exploitation of wild populations may have a serious impact on the surrounding environment.<ref>[http://www.chemeurope.com/en/encyclopedia/Epimedium.html Epimedium, ChemEurope.com]</ref>
=== Lily bulb === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} Lily bulbs (Bai He) are used in TCM to treat dry cough, dry and sore throat, and wheezing.
=== Chinese Rhubarb === {{expand section|date=September 2015}} The root of "Chinese rhubarb," or "da huang," (大黄) either ''[[Rheum palmatum]]'', or ''[[Rheum officinale]]'', is an important herb that is used primarily as a laxative in Chinese Traditional Medicine. The degree of potency depends on how long the root is cooked during preparation after harvesting.<ref>Optimized separation of pharmacologically active anthraquinones in Rhubarb by capillary electrochromatography, Yan Li, Huwei Liu, Xiuhong Ji, Junlin Li, Electrophoresis, Volume 21, Issue 15, pages 3109–3115, 1 September 2000, [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/1522-2683(20000901)21:15%3C3109::AID-ELPS3109%3E3.0.CO;2-Q/abstract]</ref>
=== Round cardamon fruit === Round cardamon fruit (Bai Dou Kou) is used in TCM to treat poor appetite, breathing problems, vomiting and diarreahea {{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
=== Thunder god vine === [[Tripterygium wilfordii|Thunder god vine]] is used in TCM to treat arthritis, relieve pain and reduce joint swelling.<ref name=TB>Lei Gong Teng (Radix Tripterygii Wilfordii): A Blessing or a Time Bomb?, John Chen, PhD, PharmD, OMD, Lac, [http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/mpacms/at/article.php?id=28365]</ref> It can be extremely toxic, if not processed properly<ref name=TB/> If used inappropriately, within two to three hours after ingestion, a patient may begin to have diarrhea, headache, dizziness, severe vomiting (sometimes with blood), chills, high fever, and irregular heart beat. Long term inproper use may result in nervous system damage.
=== Trichosanthis root === {{confusing section|date=October 2015}} In TCM, Trichosanthis Root (Radix Trichosanthis or ''Tian Hua Fen'' in Chinese), is used to clear ''heat'', generate ''fluids'' when ''heat'' injures ''fluids'' causing thirst, in the ''wasting and thirsting'' syndrome. The pairing of ''Tian Hua Fen'' and ''Zhi Mu'' had a faster, stronger and longer effect in reducing blood sugar levels than either herb alone.<ref name="chineseherbacademy.org"/>
=== Strychnine Tree seed === The seeds of the [[Strychnine tree]], ''[[Strychnos|Strychnos nux-vomica]]'', are sometimes used to treat diseases of the respiratory tract, anemia, and geriatric complaints. The active molecule is [[strychnine]], a compound often used as a [[pesticide]].<ref>[http://tcm.health-info.org/Herbology.Materia.Medica/maqianzi-properties.htm Ma Qian Zi, Chinese Medical Tools, Acupuncture.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718161808/http://tcm.health-info.org/Herbology.Materia.Medica/maqianzi-properties.htm |date=2011-07-18 }}</ref> [[Strychnine]] can also be used as a [[stimulant]] - however it has an extremely low [[therapeutic index]] and better, less toxic replacements are available.<ref>''Materia Medica, Dan Besky, p.1050</ref>
=== Sweet wormwood === {{Main|Artemisia annua}}
{{See also|Artemisinin}}
Sweet wormwood (''[[Artemisia annua]]'', Qing Hao) is believed under TCM to treat fever, headache, dizziness, stopping bleeding, and alternating fever and chills.
Sweet wormwood had fallen out of common use under TCM until it was rediscovered in the 1970s when the ''[[Chinese Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergency Treatments]]'' (340 AD) was found. This [[pharmacopeia]] contained recipes for a tea from dried leaves, prescribed for fevers (not specifically [[malaria]]). The plant extracts often used in TCM are [[antimalarial]], due to the presence of [[artemisinin]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Duke SO, Paul RN |title=Development and Fine Structure of the Glandular Trichomes of ''Artemisia annua L.'' |journal=Int. J. Plant Sci. |volume=154 |issue=1 |pages=107–18 |year=1993 |doi=10.1086/297096 |jstor=2995610}}<br/>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ferreira JF, Janick J |title=Floral Morphology of ''Artemisia annua'' with Special Reference to Trichomes |journal=Int. J. Plant Sci. |volume=156 |issue=6 |pages=807 |year=1995 |doi=10.1086/297304}}</ref>
However, it has been questioned as to whether tea made from ''A. annua'' is effective against [[malaria]], since artemesinin is not soluble in water and the resulting tea would not be expected to contain any significant amount of artemesinin.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Mueller MS, Runyambo, Wagner I| title=Randomized controlled trial of a traditional preparation of ''Artemisia annua'' L. (Annual Wormwood) in the treatment of malaria | journal=Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg | year=2004 | volume=98 | pages=318–21 | doi=10.1016/j.trstmh.2003.09.001 | pmid=15109558 | issue=5|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title=Pharmacokinetic study of artemisinin after oral intake of a traditional preparation of ''Artemisia annua'' L. (annual wormwood) | url=http://www.ajtmh.org/cgi/content/full/70/2/128 | date=1 February 2004 |vauthors=Räth K, Taxis K, Walz GH, etal | journal=Am J Trop Med Hyg | volume=70 | pages=128–32 | pmid=14993622 | issue=2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Jansen FH | title=The herbal tea approach for artemesinin as a therapy for malaria? | journal=Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg | year=2006 | volume=100 | issue=3 | pages=285–6 | doi=10.1016/j.trstmh.2005.08.004 | pmid=16274712 }}</ref>
=== Willow bark === ''See also [[Aspirin]]''
[[Willow|Plants of the genus ''Salix'']] have been used since the time of [[Hippocrates]] (400 BC) when patients were advised to chew on the bark to reduce fever and inflammation. Willow bark has been used throughout the centuries in China and Europe to the present for the treatment of pain (particularly low back pain and [[osteoarthritis]]), [[headache]], and inflammatory conditions such as [[bursitis]] and [[tendinitis]]. The bark of white willow contains salicin, which is a chemical similar to aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid). It is thought to be responsible for the pain-relieving and anti-inflammatory effects of the herb. In 1829, salicin was used to develop aspirin. White willow appears to be slower than aspirin to bring pain relief, but its effects may last longer.<ref>[http://www.umm.edu/altmed/articles/willow-bark-000281.htm]</ref>
== Minerals == === Arsenic === {{Further|Arsenic}} [[Realgar|Arsenic sulfide]] (Xiong Huang) is a toxic mineral used in TCM to kill [[parasitic worms]] and treat sore throats, swellings, abscesses, itching, rashes, and malaria.<ref name=plos>Genuis SJ, Schwalfenberg G, Siy A-KJ, Rodushkin I (2012) [http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0049676#pone.0049676-Woolf1 '' Toxic Element Contamination of Natural Health Products and Pharmaceutical Preparations'']. PLOS ONE 7(11): e49676. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0049676</ref><ref name=RA>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/realgar.php Realgar, Acupuncture Today]</ref>
Arsenic, while possibly essential for life in tiny amounts, is extremely toxic in the amounts used and [[arsenic poisoning]] may result from improper use of arsenic containing remedies.<ref name=RA/> They are most commonly given as a pill or capsule, although are sometimes incorporated into a mixture with other substances.<ref name=RA/>
=== Lead === [[Galena]] is used in TCM to treat ringworm, skin disorders and ulcers, and is thought to "detoxify" the body.<ref name=gat>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/galena.php Galena, Acupuncture Today]</ref> It is crushed and taken orally or used on the skin.<ref name=gat/> [[Lead tetroxide]] (Qian Dan) is used to treat anxiety, itching, and malaria.<ref name=plos/><ref>[http://www.tcmassistant.com/herbs/qian-dan.html Qian Dan (Minium)], TCM Assistant.</ref><ref>[http://www.americandragon.com/Individualherbsupdate/QianDan.html Qian Dan], American Dragon.</ref><ref>[http://www.rootdown.us/Qian-Dan Qian Dan : lead elixir : minium, lead oxide], rootdown.us.</ref> It is important to note that most lead compounds are extremely toxic.
=== Mercury === {{Further|Mercury poisoning}}
==== Cinnabar ==== Despite its [[toxic]]ity, [[mercury sulfide]] ([[cinnabar]]) has historically been used in Chinese medicine, where it is called ''zhūshā'' ([[wikt:朱砂|朱砂]]), and was highly valued in [[Chinese alchemy|Chinese Alchemy]]. It was also referred to as ''dān'' ([[wikt:丹|丹]]), meaning{{vague|date=October 2016}} all of [[Chinese alchemy]], cinnabar, and the "elixir of immortality". [[Cinnabar]] has been used in Traditional Chinese medicine as a sedative for more than 2000 years, and has been shown to have sedative and toxic effects in mice.<ref name=NEC>''"Neurotoxicological effects of cinnabar (a Chinese mineral medicine, HgS) in mice"'', ''Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology'', Volume 224, Issue 2, 15 October 2007, Chun-Fa Huanga, Shing-Hwa Liua and Shoei-Yn Lin-Shiau, Pages 192-201, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WXH-4P6M5YG-5&_user=10&_coverDate=10%2F15%2F2007&_alid=1627583906&_rdoc=23&_fmt=high&_orig=search&_origin=search&_zone=rslt_list_item&_cdi=7159&_docanchor=&view=c&_ct=1074&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=61a19e1e0edf644fb9d3a4eb469bef23&searchtype=a]</ref> In addition to being used for insomnia, cinnabar is thought to be effective for cold sores, sore throat, and some skin infections.<ref>[http://www.acupuncturetoday.com/herbcentral/cinnabar.php ''Cinnabar''], Acupuncture Today.</ref>
==== Corrosive sublimate ==== [[Mercury(II) chloride]] (''Qing Fen'') is used in TCM to "detoxify" the body, kill intestinal parasites, and as a mild tranquilizer.<ref name=plos/><ref>[http://www.bcmj.org/letters/mercury-and-chinese-herbal-medicine '' Mercury and Chinese herbal medicine''], H.C. George Wong, MD, BCMJ, Vol. 46, No. 9, November 2004, page(s) 442 Letters.</ref>

{{Redirect|Little Rock}} {{Use American English|date=May 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Short description|Capital of Arkansas}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Little Rock, Arkansas | settlement_type = [[List of capitals in the United States|State capital]] and [[city]] | official_name = City of Little Rock | image_skyline = Little Rock collage.png | image_caption = Clockwise from top: Little Rock skyline, [[William J.
